dublinCore.dc:title: 119 HR 1546 IH: Erie Canal Bicentennial Commemorative Coin Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Ms. Tenney introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Financial Services

form.official-title: To require the Secretary of the Treasury to mint coins in recognition of the bicentennial of the Erie Canal.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Erie Canal Bicentennial Commemorative Coin Act.

paragraph.text: Built between 1817 and 1825, the original Erie Canal traversed 363 miles from Albany to Buffalo.
The Erie Canal was the longest artificial waterway and the greatest public works project in North America.

The Erie Canal was one of the most important steps in the United States initiating its industrial revolution, rapidly increasing the productivity of agriculture and the spread of machinery and manufactured goods.
The Erie Canal cut the travel time between Albany and Buffalo in half and reduced freight rates by 90 percent. This allowed midwestern farmers and industry to have new access to distant markets.

The Erie Canal opened up the American interior for settlement and enabled a new flow of people and ideas. This fueled social reform movements such as abolitionism, women’s suffrage, utopian communities, and multiple religious movements along the canal corridor.
The Erie Canal continues to define the geography of upstate New York with 80 percent of the upstate New York population living withing 25 miles of the corridor.
After 200 years the Erie Canal is still a resource for its local communities as a close to home recreational destination for boaters, bikers, and walkers.

subsection.text: The Secretary of the Treasury (hereafter in this Act referred to as the Secretary) shall mint and issue the following coin:

paragraph.text: Not more than 50,000 $5 coins, which shall—

subparagraph.text: have a diameter of 0.850 inches; and
contain not less than 90 percent gold.

paragraph.text: Not more than 400,000 $1 coins, which shall—

subparagraph.text: have a diameter of 1.500 inches; and
contain not less than 90 percent silver.

paragraph.text: Not more than 750,000 half-dollar coins which shall—

subparagraph.text: have a diameter of 1.205 inches; and
be minted to the specifications for half-dollar coins contained in section 5112(b) of title 31, United States Code.

subsection.text: The coins minted under this Act shall be legal tender, as provided in section 5103 of title 31, United States Code.
For purposes of sections 5134 and 5136 of title 31, United States Code, all coins minted under this Act shall be considered to be numismatic items.

paragraph.text: The designs of the coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of the Erie Canal and its impact on the development of the United States and New York State.
On each coin minted under this Act there shall be—

subparagraph.text: a designation of the value of the coin;
an inscription of the year 2026; and
inscriptions of the words Liberty, In God We Trust, United States of America, and E Pluribus Unum.

subsection.text: The design for the coins minted under this Act shall be—

paragraph.text: selected by the Secretary after consultation with—

subparagraph.text: the Commission of Fine Arts; and
Erie Canalway Heritage Fund, Inc.; and

paragraph.text: reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee.

subsection.text: Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities.
The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act only during the 1-year period beginning on January 1, 2026.
The coins issued under this Act shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the sum of—

paragraph.text: the face value of the coins;
the surcharge provided in section 7(a) with respect to such coins; and
the cost of designing and issuing the coins (including labor, materials, dies, use of machinery, overhead expenses, marketing, and shipping).

subsection.text: The Secretary shall make bulk sales of the coins issued under this Act at a reasonable discount.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall accept prepaid orders for the coins minted under this Act before the issuance of such coins.
Sale prices with respect to prepaid orders under paragraph (1) shall be at a reasonable discount.

subsection.text: All sales of coins issued under this Act shall include a surcharge of—

paragraph.text: $35 per coin for the $5 coin;
$10 per coin for the $1 coin; and
$5 per coin for the half-dollar coin.

subsection.text: Subject to section 5134(f) of title 31, United States Code, all surcharges received by the Secretary from the sale of coins issued under this Act shall be promptly paid by the Secretary to the Erie Canalway Heritage Fund, Inc., to support the historic preservation, conservation, recreation, interpretation, tourism, and community development of the Erie Canalway National Heritage Corridor and for educational and commemorative programs of the Erie Canal’s history and impact on our Nation’s history.
The recipient of surcharges under this Act shall be subject to the audit requirements of section 5134(f)(2) of title 31, United States Code, with regard to the amounts received under subsection (b).

Notwithstanding subsection (a), no surcharge may be included with respect to the issuance under this Act of any coin during a calendar year if, as of the time of such issuance, the issuance of such coin would result in the number of commemorative coin programs issued during such year to exceed the annual 2 commemorative coin program issuance limitation under section 5112(m)(1) of title 31, United States Code (as in effect on the date of the enactment of this Act). The Secretary may issue guidance to carry out this subsection.

section.text: The Secretary shall take such actions as may be necessary to ensure that—

paragraph.text: minting and issuing coins under this Act will not result in any net cost to the United States Government; and

no funds, including applicable surcharges, shall be disbursed to any recipient designated in section 7 until the total cost of designing and issuing all of the coins authorized by this Act (including labor, materials, dies, use of machinery, overhead expenses, marketing, and shipping) is recovered by the United States Treasury, consistent with sections 5112(m) and 5134(f) of title 31, United States Code.
